prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling a friend he is being creepy and pathetic following a breakup?
My friend was with this girl for about eight months. He is 22.

While he was with her, he would go on and on about how she was "the one" and how they were going to get married, etc. 

She recently broke up with him because he was moving way too fast in the relationship and he needs time to work on himself and deal with his anxiety.

He completely lost it after this. We ended up having to call 911 and have him taken to the hospital because he was calling her and us threatening harm on himself. 

He constantly calls her asking why she can't take him back, and he told us that if she's in the city, he might go to her place and "ask her in person". 

Well, me and my friends all took turns spending time with him after the hospital visit and on my turn I just lost it after hearing for the fifth time how he was going to "get her back."

I told him he was being creepy and pathetic and that she has made it abundantly clear that she doesn't want to get back together with him and he needs to stop all this behavior. 

He got really pissed and kicked me out of his apartment.

My friends told me that I probably could have done it in a nicer way but that they agree with me.

So AITA for telling him all that?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The question is whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong for telling their friend he's being creepy and pathetic after a breakup. Let's break down the situation.

First, the friend was in an eight-month relationship where he kept saying she was "the one" and they'd get married. The girl broke up because he was moving too fast and needed to work on himself and his anxiety. After the breakup, the friend had a mental breakdown, called 911, and even threatened self-harm. He kept contacting her, trying to get back together, and even thought about showing up at her place. The author, after spending time with him and hearing this multiple times, told him he was being creepy and pathetic, leading to him getting kicked out.

The author's friends agree with them but think they could have been nicer. The question is, is the author in the wrong for speaking out?

Well, the friend's behavior sounds obsessive and potentially stalking. After a breakup, contacting the ex repeatedly, especially with intent to pressure them, is generally considered unhealthy and can be legally problematic. The author is pointing out that the friend is behaving in a way that's creepy and not acceptable. Even though the friend is dealing with emotional issues, the author is trying to help him see the reality of his actions.

But was the author wrong in how they communicated this? They might have been harsh, but the message was valid. The friend's actions are harmful, not just to the ex but also to himself. The author's friends agree, which suggests that the sentiment was necessary. However, the way it was delivered could have been more compassionate. But the core message—that the friend is acting inappropriately—is correct. So the author isn't in the wrong for pointing this out, even if the delivery could have been better. The key is that the friend needs to stop his behavior, and the author is trying to help. So the answer would be B (No, the author isn't in the wrong).
